items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely through this evening, Sunday 7th November, and overnight into tomorrow morning.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Monday 8th November.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.71 mAOD at 04:15 on 08/11/21 and 4.77 mAOD at 17:00 on 08/11/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 39 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 08/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 11:30pm tonight, Sunday 7th November, and 3:30am tomorrow. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.79mAODN at 1:30am tomorrow, Monday 8th November, which is 0.34m above tide tables, wind Force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Monday 8th November.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
The risk of flooding along the Northumberland Coast has now reduced.  
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
We will continue to monitor the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: High water levels are forecast this evening as a result of spring tides and strong winds. Forecast high water is 20:30 on 7/11/21 with a level of 6.30 mAOD and a Force 4 North Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland may be possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions should ease, and tidal levels fall, for the 8/11/21 high tide at 08:45. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Monday, 8/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30pm tonight, Sunday 7th November, and 3:30am tomorrow. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.65vmAODN at 1:30am tomorrow, Monday 8th November, which is 0.51m above tide tables, wind Force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Monday 8th November.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.65mAODN at 1:30am tomorrow, Monday 8th November, which is 0.51m above tide tables, wind Force 4, North Westerly. items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
High tidal levels are expected to overtop sea defences.  Forecast high water is at 21:00 on 07/11/21 with a level of 7.45 mAOD and a Force 4 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.   Coastal conditions should ease for the high tide at 09:15 on 08/11/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Monday, 08/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: The unsettled weather which brought reasonably strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast today, is slowly clearing the area. This afternoon’s tide at Portsmouth (12:45 07/11/21) came in 5 cm over forecast. Throughout the coming week, tides will move from Spring to Neap cycles and will therefore be significantly lower than today. We are not expecting further impacts as a result.

The Coast road at Walcott may see some wave overtopping and spray.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.10mAODN at 7:45pm, on Sunday 7th November, which is 0.75m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly, which will be blowing strongly offshore. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation.  We will update this message by 9:30am tomorrow, Monday 8th November.

items.description: Tidal River Aire catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: This flood alert is being removed as, due to offshore winds overnight, this morning’s tide was not as high as expected.  Another high spring tide, currently forecast to be a little lower than this morning’s one, is expected this evening between 8:30 to 10:30 pm. Tidal levels will be falling going into next week. Following this morning’s high tide, our operational staff are checking our flood embankments and other defences in the area. Please keep away from flood water and to report an issue relating to river, tidal or coastal flooding, call our Incident Hotline 0800 80 70 60. Be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation via our Check for Flooding Service on Gov.UK or via Floodline 0345 988 1188.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.78mAODN at 10:45pm, on Sunday 7th November, which is 0.7m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, River Don, Dutch River

items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to the possibility of minor impacts from tidal and coastal flooding on Sunday 7th November. Due to offshore winds overnight, this morning’s tide was not as high as expected.  Another high spring tide, currently forecast to be a little lower, or a similar height to this morning’s one, is expected this evening between 8:30 to 9:30 pm. Following this morning’s high tide, our operational staff are checking our flood embankments and other defences in the area. We anticipate removing this flood alert on Monday morning, as tidal levels fall going into next week. Please keep away from flood water and to report an issue relating to river, tidal or coastal flooding, call our Incident Hotline 0800 80 70 60. Be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation via our Check for Flooding Service on Gov.UK or via Floodline 0345 988 1188. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. items.description: Selsey Bill to Elmer
items.message: The unsettled weather which brought elevated tide levels along the south coast is now clearing the area. Monday's early morning tide on 08/11/2021 (01:15) at Littlehampton is predicted to be 25 cm lower than it was Sunday afternoon and accompanied with lighter winds and smaller waves. None, or very minimal, flood impacts are expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level Monday morning will be 5.83 metres Chart Datum (3.09 mAOD). Each subsequent tide through the next week will be lower again. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: High water levels are forecast to affect the foreshore from Ramsgate to Kingsdown in the early hours of tomorrow morning, Monday 08/11/2021, as a result of continuing high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 00:00 and 01:00 tomorrow morning, Monday 08/11/2021, with high tide at 00:30. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea and low lying land along the tidal Stour. Flooding to properties is not expected. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are prepared to respond if required. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/11/2021, or as the situation changes. For those that use it, the astronomical water level will be 3.16m AOD and the total water level will be 3.62m AOD.

items.description: Irish Sea at New Brighton
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.   

The risk of flooding from the Irish Sea has now reduced on 07/11/2021.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.   

We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue the warning if necessary.

items.description: North Sea at Roker, Sunderland
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
The risk of flooding from the North Sea has now reduced.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Irish Sea from New Brighton to Hoylake
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold on 07/11/2021. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue the alert if necessary.

items.description: North Sea at Alnmouth
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
The risk of flooding from the North Sea has now reduced.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with local authorities.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Areas near the tidal River Welland, tidal River Nene, and the Wash

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Welland, River Nene, The Wash

items.message: Stormy conditions have now past. The risk of tidal flooding for areas near the tidal river Welland, tidal river Nene and the Wash has now reduced and has fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Bacton to Ostend, including Walcott
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is possible between 5:45pm and 9:45pm Sunday 7th November. Areas most at risk are Sea View, Ann Stannard Way, Keswick Way, and Walcott Rd. The Coast Rd, St Helens Rd, Helena Rd, Poplar Dr, Archibald Rd, Lynton Rd, The Crescent and Ostend Place in Walcott. Seaview Crescent, Ostend Gap, Ostend Rd and Horizon Views. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.10mAODN at 7:45pm, on Sunday 7th November, which is 0.75m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 9:30am tomorrow, Monday 8th November.
